captions.text:
We're all familiar with gravity as "the reason
objects fall", but there's much, much more
to gravity than that.

Gravity is a long range attractive force between
all objects with mass:

it's what keeps us from falling off the earth,
it's what keeps the earth in orbit around

the sun, and it's what caused the sun itself
to form four and a half billion years ago!

It's amazing to think that every massive object
attracts every other in the universe –

that means that your dog, the earth,
and a black hole in the Andromeda galaxy 2.5

million light years away
are all gravitationally attracted to you,
and you to them.

In the 17th century, Isaac Newton discovered
that the strength of the gravitational force

decreases by the square of the distance between
two objects – so if you're twice as far

away, gravity is only one fourth as strong!
He also discovered that the strength of gravity

is proportional to the mass of the objects
in question: the more massive an object, the

stronger the gravitational force. That's why
we can all feel the Earth pulling on us, but

don't really notice the pull of the moon – it's
smaller, and farther away! (the moon's gravity
is strong enough to cause the tides, though!)

And when I said earlier that gravity is an
attraction between objects with mass, I lied.

I meant objects with Energy. Because in addition
to massive objects, gravity also attracts

light and other massless (but energetic) particles,
so that a photon of light can be bent slightly

passing the sun, or trapped completely by
a black hole.
Now do you understand the Gravity of the situation?

comments.text:
+CrystalRubyMoon Supposedly the "graviton." However, gravity is too weak to 
detect individual gravitons with any equipment or experiments we have. This 
actually conforms with all theories of gravitons we have because they 
should be very weak. It takes a lot of mass to have a decent strength 
gravity field.

However, Einstein came up with the idea of General Relativity. In this 
theory an object in a gravity well (like Earth's surface) goes through time 
slower relative to an object far away from gravity.


This effect has been measured. Time is running a little bit faster in space 
than it is on Earth's surface. It is important to note: no local observer 
will ever sense the effect because for Earth it is a TINY amount and all of 
an object's immediate surroundings will be slowed down just as much anyway 
(so the relative effect over distances needs to be measured). This slow 
down of an object moving through time causes a speed up of the object 
through space. The energy has to be conserved somehow. This is the 
acceleration of gravity you feel. 


Your body and everything else is made up of little fields (per Quantum 
Field Theory). Gravity has the effect of slowing down the bottom of the 
fields a little bit more than the top of the field. This creates a downward 
force and as an object slows down through time relative to free space it 
accelerates. A very small slow down in time yields a huge speed up because 
C = space/time = 300,000,000 m/s.


Gravity is


1) The warping (curving) of spacetime which causes an acceleration.


2) Gravity should be caused by a gaviton and the gravity field it creates 
but no theory of gravity has been proven.


3) Gravity also warps space because v*t = d and c which is a constant has 
the equation c*t = d so if t warps then so does d. When acceleration 
happens c may not be a constant for the accelerating observer but the idea 
of space warping with time is still correct.


BTW the "exact" understanding of anything in the natural world will never 
be known. Scientists do seem to have some understanding of gravity but it's 
far from complete.

A more massive object does not fall "faster" due to gravity.  The force 
from gravity is indeed stronger on more massive things - in fact the force 
is directly proportional to mass.  If the mass doubles, the force of 
gravity doubles.  The acceleration due to that force is the same.  It 
doesn't change.  From the same height, any two objects will accelerate at 
the exact same rate regardless of the fact that the force from gravity 
acting on them is different.

comments.text:
The inverse square law applies to many areas of physics.  Not just 
electromagnetism or radiation.  Anything that has a radiating quality to 
it.  Light, gravity, radiation, electromagnetism, etc.  I assume that you 
do not understand WHY the inverse square law applies to so many areas of 
physics.  The reason is because things that have a radiating quality to 
them radiate outward in spherical shapes.  If you measure the 'intensity' 
of a quantity along the surface of that imaginary sphere, you would find 
that no matter how big that sphere is, the total magnitude is the same.  So 
if you take a square centimeter of a smaller sphere and compare that to a 
square cm of a larger sphere, the 'intensity' of that square cm will be 
smaller on the larger sphere because it's taking up a smaller percentage of 
the whole, right?  By what factor?  Well, by the same factor that the 
surface area of that sphere increases.  That makes sense, right?  So what 
is the surface area of a sphere?  4πr².  The term 4π is constant, so the 
only factor that matters is r² or the radius squared.  The surface area 
increases by a factor of the square of the radius, so the 'intensity' of 
that square cm DECREASES by the same factor.  Thus, it is inversely 
proportional to the square of the radius.  And this inverse square law 
applies all over the place in physics.  Pick up your books some more, there 
guy.
comments.author: Willoughby Krenzteinburg

comments.text:
It is a great debate opportunity that this site has created and my utmost 
gratitude is conveyed at first.
Sir Isaac Newton has explained only the physical parameters of the 
phenomenon called Gravity. The phenomenon is explained if only the 
mechanism behind 'how Gravity attracts things' is explained. And the 
scientists of the mediator period have made it more complex to become a 
paradox by their philosophic definitions which could never be proven 
practically or mathematically. I firmly believe Scientists of the 21st 
century can solve this paradox unless they really want to conserve it as a 
paradox for the future generations to solve. 

Students of logical thinking should ask the questions; 
1. Why Gravity does only attract things and why it doesn't repel ? 
2. Why Gravity attract only 'atomic mass' and why not 'energy mass' like 
photon, electrons, solar wind etc? 

Before answering above questions we have to clarify 'what are the three 
fundamental space matter?' Soils, Liquids and gasses must be the sure 
answer from a student of junior secondary level. But we know that are the 
three phases of the atomic mass.Then what matter is electron's, light and 
heat etc? Do not they posses a mass? That category of matter has to be 
recognized as 'Energy Mass'. Solar wind too belongs to that category 
because it is made up of weakly charged  energy particles emitted from Sun. 
Then what is the third category of fundamental space matter? It is the 
'Space Medium Matter'. The space is densely filled with this invisible 
static matter and it has a density and a pressure.

Now only the mechanism of Gravity can be explained because the different 
behaviour of energy waves and energy rays could not be distinguished until 
a space medium of matter is accepted. Energy rays like light, heat X-ray 
etc. dont need a medium to travel because they are line projection of 
energy particles like photons. But waves such as, natural sounds, 
electromagnetic FM or AM sounds, TV etc always need a medium to travel.

Gravity too is due to a medium wave and how could it born? 
Put a fly in to a calm water and you would observe tiny waves round and 
round. That is how atomic masses produce gravitational wave in the space 
medium. A single atom can be considered as a rotary engine in which 
electron clouds are rotating round the nucleus. Any rotary machine in the 
world makes a vibration and a bigger collection of atomic mass makes a 
stronger vibration to transmit a stronger wave through the medium. That is 
how the gravitational waves are born but how on earth it can attract 
another mass?

When the wave strike upon any secondary atom in the field, the rotating 
electron cloud is a bit pushed more closer to the nucleus from the 
direction at where the wave strikes from. Thence the Coulomb's 
electromagnetic force at the side of wave strike becomes bigger and the 
resultant force makes the atom move towards the gravity source. Electrons 
and photons are not responded by gravity because they don't have internal 
rotary systems to be affected. 

Other most important thing is that, dynamic behaviour of gravitational 
fields has not yet even touched. Only the static gravitation was explained 
in Newtonian Mechanics.But you know Sun is rotating and its gravitational 
field is not static at all. Therefore the gravity of Sun is deviated due to 
rotation and as a result an orbital motive force is applied upon planets to 
orbit in the same direction of Suns rotation.

However ultimately the credit of Gravity has to be shared with Coulomb too 
because his electromagnetism could explain the mechanism of so mysterious 
magical force of gravity.  ﻿

massive) objects. Learn as much as you can about magnets and atoms and you 
may be able to understand what "gravity" is (or is not) better.

I still think anti-gravity is possible, but gravity as a force may not have 
a polarity for which we can discover the opposite. There is no "anti-light" 
that I am aware of (except a mirror.) so maybe there is no anti-gravity.

I guess you could say the N pole of one magnet was the anti-magnet of the N 
pole of a different magnet.﻿

the other right past the bowling ball's spot, the ball will get sucked down 
in next to it by the "droop" (AKA gravity) the bowling ball leaves in the 
sheet. Now, the droop is much less intense on the edges of the sheet rather 
than right next to the ball, so if a small enough or fast enough ball is

and eventually make it past. This however is a crude analogy in comparison 
to the real deal, but might help one understand where gravity comes from.﻿

comments.text:
You can think of it in both ways.  In classical mechanics, it is a mutual 
force between two objects of mass that is proportional to the product of 
their masses.  For the vast majority of situations you will probably ever 
encounter in your life, this works just fine.

In general relativity, gravity is not a force, but a curvature of space 
time.  Both space itself and time itself are affected by the presence of 
energy/momentum - including mass.  Not really a 'wrinkle' in space-time, 
but that's not really important.

It might help if you understood a little bit about *why* Einstein concluded 
that gravity could not be a force.

Hopefully, you remember a little about Newton's laws of motion.  
Specifically, the first law - which states that an object in motion will 
remain in motion unless an unbalanced force acts on it.  The law of 
inertia.  Also, it is important to understand that the physical laws of the 
universe are applicable in all inertial reference frames.  An inertial 
reference frame is a frame of reference where this first law applies.  In 
other words, if you are in a frame of reference, and an object undergoing 
no forces moves in a straight line with constant velocity, then you are in 
an inertial reference frame.  The reference frame itself is experiencing no 
forces and no accelerations.

When you stand on the surface of the Earth and you hold a ball out with 
your hand and let go, what happens?  The ball falls to the ground, right?  
In Newton's world, this is because a force acted on the ball - namely 
Gravity. 

However, in Einstein's world, the opposite is happening.  Think about being 
in a rocket very far away from all gravitational sources where there are no 
forces acting on you.  Suppose that rocket fired its engines and 
accelerated (in any direction) at a constant 9.8 m/s².  What would happen 
to you?  You would be pushed to one side of the rocket, right?  The side of 
the rocket opposite the direction it was accelerating in.  If you held a 
ball out of your hand, and let go - that ball would accelerate toward that 
end of the rocket at 9.8 m/s² from your perspective because its not gravity 
that is accelerating the ball toward the floor, but the rocket which is 
accelerating forward making it APPEAR that it is accelerating to the floor 
from your perspective.  Einstein concluded that there was no difference 
between standing firmly on the ground within a gravitational field and 
being in a rocket in deep space being accelerated at a rate equal to the 
gravitational acceleration at that point in that gravitational field.  
There is no experiment that you could perform that could differentiate 
between these two frames.  They are identical (locally).  Therefore, 
standing on the surface of the Earth is actually accelerated motion.  
Conversely, there is no experiment you could perform that could 
differentiate between being far away in deep space floating inside a box, 
and being inside that same box while free falling in a gravitational 
field.  There is no difference.  These two frames are identical.  If you 
float a ball inside a box where you, the ball, and the box are all free 
falling inside a gravitational field, then that ball will perfectly obey 
the law of inertia.  It will continue in a straight line with a constant 
velocity - - - which means that free falling in a gravitational field is 
inertial motion - - and THAT means that there are no forces acting on that 
frame of reference.  Therefore, gravity can not be a force.


This can be demonstrated very clearly by astronauts in orbit around the 
Earth.  Notice that when they exert forces on objects, they just float away 
at a constant speed until they hit a wall, or some other object - or force 
acts on them.  These objects are following the law of inertia - which means 
that the frame of reference they are in is inertial - or not accelerating.  
According to Newton, free fall is accelerated motion caused by the force of 
gravity.  When you really understand the law of inertia, you can clearly 
see that those astronauts free falling in orbit around the Earth are in an 
inertial reference frame, therefore not accelerating, and if they are not 
accelerating, then there are not forces acting on them.  Not even gravity.


These days, it is very clear that free fall is inertial motion, but in 
Einstein's time, people just didn't go around free falling, so it was 
actually a quite intuitive discovery to realize that free falling in a 
gravitational field is inertial motion and identical to having no forces 
acting on you.

comments.text:
Tony - don't block replies if you want answers to your question.

That is the point.  Mass is irrelevant with regards to the acceleration due 
to gravity. 

You can't say that "gravity has nothing to do with mass".

You CAN say that the *ACCELERATION* due to gravity has nothing to do with 
mass.  The FORCE of gravity does depend on mass, but since there is a such 
thing as inertia, the more mass an object has, the more inertia it has - 
the harder it is to accelerate, so it requires a greater force to 
accelerate a more massive object at the same rate as a lesser massive 
object.  This proportionality here is in balance.  All objects will 
accelerate at the same rate because the force is greater on greater masses, 
but it requires that much more force to accelerate it at the same rate.﻿

OK, I've always hated the bowling-ball-in-a sheet visualization of gravity 
curving spacetime, since spacetime, obviously, is not a flat surface. And 
since the mass of an object warps spacetime in THREE dimension, essentially 
causing space to PUSH TOWARD the object (and not the object PULL matter 
towards it) - please (please) give me you thoughts on the following 
visualization:

Imagine spacetime is a clear gelatin that's 12 inches cubed. Then, imagine 
a tennis ball growing in the center of that clear gelatin cube. Ok? Got it? 
Now, if we imagine that the growth of that tennis ball DISPLACES the 
"gelatinous spacetime," then pressure is built up all around that tennis 
ball. The pressure at the surface of that tennis ball would be the highest 
since the "gelatinous spacetime" there would be most "bunched up," if you 
will. Further away, there would be very little "bunching up" of spacetime, 
and the pressure, likewise, less.

Therefore, the result of the "desire" of spacetime to return to its 
original shape would be GRAVITY. So, in essence, could gravity be described 
as spacetime itself struggling to snap back into shape, but the mass 
(planet, tennis ball) gets in the way?

Of course, my ignorant theory assumes that spacetime has some unknown 
"invisible gelatinous connectivity," but could that "connectivity" perhaps 
be the result of another dimension of space time that we cannot perceive?﻿

comments.text:
+Visda58
  Good stuff.  I would love to be able to talk to an astrophysicist about 
this stuff, to see if the mathematical formulas that predict gravity do in 
any way match up with what you and/or I am saying.  I've tried making 
contact with a few, but with scattered results.  My visualization explains 
gravity as, basically, increased "surface tension" in the fabric of 
space-time at, say, the surface of the earth (tennis ball) pushing toward 
the center of the earth in all directions.  Close to the earth's surface = 
highest tension = highest gravity.  Further away = less tension = less 
gravity.  Nothing is disappearing into anything.  What I like about your 
model is the idea of "low pressure area."  Could gravity be explained as 
"Nature abhors a vacuum?"  Again, we may both be blowing smoke, but it's 
certainly interesting and FAR better than a 2-dimentional model!
comments.author: Christopher Rubeo

comments.text:
I, also, have been annoyed by the flat grid surface visualization that is 
so common, and I think the gelatin analogy is interesting.  However, I 
think it's backwards.  My way of visualizing it (although not completely 
fleshed out, at all) is that instead of a tennis ball growing in the center 
of the gelatin, the center of the gelatin disappears into itself (into 
nothing), creating a stretch moving toward that center.  This would cause 
the grid lines to stretch in such a way (being sucked into the center) that 
allows for accurate coordinate measurements of the movement of objects in 
the grid, (objects staying on a "straight" path) but following the 
elliptical curves of orbits as relative to the still perfectly square outer 
edges of the gelatin.  

I think this represents a better, sort of "low pressure area" around the 
center of gravity rather than a "high pressure area" as in the tennis ball 
model, which may be arbitrary and could be countered by a formula to 
reverse the positive pressure to negative for calculating orbital behavior, 
but the low pressure analogy helps to better visualize how things are 
"sucked" into a gravitational pull.  To my brain it just seems more logical.

But what is the grid disappearing into, you ask?  That's where the mystery 
of gravity starts to rear it head, but I like to think of the grid being 
sucked into the center of gravity, and then manifesting itself back into 
the grid as a small, very dense and compacted "grid lines " immediately 
surrounding the center point.  Different densities of course for different 
materials would determine how big the sphere would extend beyond the center 
back into space of the grid.  Imagine the previously regularly spaced grid 
lines turning into tightly packed strata forming a solid sphere, while the 
grid lines outside the sphere are being pulled into it, and are more 
stretched the closer they are to the sphere.  

Practically, the outside grid becomes sphere strata at the outer surface of 
the shell (accretion) and the more layers, the higher the gravity, but the 
theoretical lines of the grid continue to the center, where one could 
imagine they become strata from the inside, at the center of gravity.  In 
this way we can still visualize the forces, and use these coordinates for 
calculations.

Another question is: what is the difference between the outer grid and the 
compacted strata, besides it's density?  Is it all still "grid", or does 
the nature of the "grid" change when it becomes strata?  Does the grid 
itself attract other parts of the grid, but is only noticeable when reaches 
the event horizon of becoming strata?  Is the gelatin itself "potential 
matter"?

These last questions might betray my ignorance of the subject...

comments.text:
+Peter Shamadingdong "I don't understand what you mean by inversely 
proportional and proportional factor."

Proportional just means that the value of some *thing* decreases or 
increases at the same rate as the value of some other thing.

Suppose you have two values.  A and B.  A is proportional to B.  If B 
increase by a factor of 'x', then A also increases by a factor of 'x'.  The 
factor is what you are *multiplying* B by.  If the value for B is 10 and 
increased by a factor of 7, then B is 7 times what it was before, so 70.  
If A is proportional to B, then A is ALSO increased by a factor of 7.

Inversely proportional just means that the value DECREASES as the OTHER 
value increases, so taking the same two things, A and B, if A is inversely 
proportional to B, and B is increased by a factor of 7, then A is DECREASED 
by the same factor, and you DIVIDE by that factor

"I also didn't understand what you meant by things radiating out in a 
sphere shape, does that mean that everything radiates in a sphere shape?"

"Why is the source of gravity at the center?"

I didn't say that things radiate outward in a spherical shape.  I said it 
is ok to think about it like that.

There is a force of gravity between any two particles of mass.  Two specs 
of dust have a gravitational attraction toward one another.  There is a 
gravitational attraction between you and a pencil.  There is a 
gravitational attraction between you and a rock in Australia.  There is a 
gravitational attraction between you and a tree in California.  There is a 
gravitational attraction between you and every spec and particle of mass 
that make up the Earth.  However, since the Earth is more or less a sphere, 
and the density is relatively uniform (at least from the same distance to 
the center - meaning the density of the material at 'x' distance to the 
center is uniform), then the sum of all those forces net to the center of 
mass of the Earth.  There is nothing particularly interesting or remarkable 
AT the center of the Earth that is causing gravity.  The mass of the entire 
Earth is causing it, and the net force (the sum of all the forces between 
you and every particle of mass of the Earth) points toward the center.  If 
you are sitting on ice and you have a friend push you from behind and a 
friend push you to the left at the same time, you will go kind of 
diagonally, right?  That's because that diagonal direction is the SUM of 
the two forces.  The same applies to the Earth, and they figured out a long 
time ago that rather than actually figure out what all the individual 
forces (there would be billions of them) between some object and every 
particle of mass of a celestial object, if that celestial object is a 
sphere (and they all are pretty much), then it is a lot easier to skip that 
step and assume that the net force is toward the center of the celestial 
object, and rather than consider that celestial object as a collection of a 
bunch of different forces added together, they just consider it as a point 
mass (an infinitely small point in space) that originates at the center of 
mass of a celestial object that contains the entire mass of that celestial 
object.

Now, we all now that it is not LITERALLY a point mass that originates at 
the center that contains the entire mass of the celestial object, but it is 
OK to think about it like that because there is no difference.  It might as 
well be, and it makes all the calculations FAR easier.

The same thing applies to the notion that you can think of gravity as a 
sphere that radiates outward.  It doesn't literally do that, but 
mathematically it does, and it makes the calculations a lot easier to think 
about it like that.

"Why does the increase in radius determine the surface area increase, and 
why at that factor."

Since it is OK to think about the force of gravity as a sphere radiating 
outward from the center of the Earth, then we can ignore the Earth to 
answer this question, and only think about the geometry of a sphere.

The radius of a sphere is the distance between the center of that sphere 
and the surface of that sphere.  Isn't it common sense that if the radius 
increases, then the surface area increases?  A basketball has a larger 
surface area than a baseball.  The Earth has a larger surface area than the 
moon.

Why at that factor?  Because that's just how the geometry of a sphere 
works.  I already talked about this.  The equation to determine the surface 
area of a sphere is 4πr².  The 'r' in that equation is the radius of a 
sphere.  Just do the math.  What if r = 1m?

4 * π * 1²
4 * 3.14 * 1 * 1 = 12.56m²

What if you double 'r' and make it 2m?

4 * 3.14 * 2 * 2 = 50.24m² (4 times 12.56)

What if you triple 'r' and make it 3m?

4 * 3.14 * 3 * 3 = 113.04m² (9 times 12.56)

As you can see, the surface area of that sphere is increasing in proportion 
to the SQUARE of the radius because the SQUARE of the radius determines the 
surface area of that sphere.  When the radius is twice as much (2X), the 
surface area increases by a factor of 4 (which is 2²).  When the radius is 
3 times as much (3X), then the surface area is increased by a factor of 9 
(3²).  If you increased the radius by a factor of 123, then the surface 
area would increase by a factor of 123².  This making sense?

Have you ever seen a balloon that had something printed on it, and when you 
blew it up, the picture or words spread out over the balloon, but as it 
spread out as the balloon got bigger, the ink did not appear to be as 
dark?  The reason for this is because you are spreading out that ink over a 
larger area.  It's the same amount of ink as it was before you began 
blowing up a balloon.  Now, gravity doesn't literally work this way, but 
you CAN think of it this way to understand this problem.  The amount of 
gravity that is on the outside of that balloon is exactly the same no 
matter how big the balloon is - - just like the ink in my example.  The 
bigger the balloon gets, the 'lighter' gravity gets just like the lighter 
the ink gets.

Now, let's just give an arbitrary value to the gravity on that balloon.  
1,000.  The entire surface of the balloon has a gravitational force of 
1,000 (units aren't important because this is a purely mathematical 
concept).

Now, when our sphere earlier had a radius of 1 m, the surface area of that 
sphere was 12.56 m².  So, the force of gravity over that entire sphere is 
1,000 no matter how big the sphere is remember?  How would that be spread 
over that sphere?

You'd just DIVIDE the surface area by the 'force'.  So

1,000 / 12.56 = 79.6 units of gravity per meter²

What about the sphere with a radius of 2 m?  Remember, it had a surface 
area of 50.24m².

Well, remember, the force of gravity over that whole surface is the same, 
so still 1,000

1,000 / 50.24 = 19.9 units of gravity per meter²

Radius of 3?

1,000 / 113.04 = 8.85 units of gravity per meter²

Now, this isn't actually how it works.  I'm just trying to explain why the 
math works the way it does.

Think of the "units of gravity per meter" as the local force due to 
gravity, and that force is inversely proportional to the SQUARE of the 
radius.

When the radius was 1, the local gravity was 79.6.

When the radius was 2 (2X) the local gravity was 19.9 (79.6/2²)

When the radius was 3 (3X) the local gravity was 8.8 (79.6/3²).

All this being said, and I know it is a lot.  You might not be ready.  It's 
cool that you want to know all of this stuff before you are taught in 
school, but don't get frustrated if you don't understand it.  The fact that 
you are asking these question at what I assume to be a fairly early age is 
testament to the fact that you are already ahead of 95% of other people 
your age.  I'm not a teacher.  So, just because you don't understand me 
doesn't mean that you can't understand it.  It's quite possible that I am a 
poor teacher!!!!

comments.text:
+Peter Shamadingdong the formula that describes gravitational interaction 
is F = G*M*m/d^2

Which means the Force of gravity is equal to the Gravitational constant 
times the mass of the first object times the mass of the second object 
divided by the square of the distance between both.

By dividing the force by the distance, it means that the greater the 
distance, the smaller the force (inversely proportional).

Also the distance is squared; for every small distance added, the formula 
is divided by an even greater amount.

If you increase the radius of a circle, the area increases too. That, 
combined that gravity radiates spherically, makes the formula be divided by 
the distance squared (Area of a circle = pi * radius squared).

comments.text:
The distance between two objects times the distance between two objects.  
It is the inverse square law, and lots of fundamental physics concepts 
follow it. 

As far as gravity is concerned, it means that if an object moves twice as 
far away, the gravitational force is 1/4 of what it was.  If you triple the 
distance, the force is 1/9 of what it was.  If you quadruple the distance, 
the force is 1/16 of what it was.  On and on and on.  The force of gravity 
is *inversely* proportional to the square of the distance.  If the distance 
is 5, the proportional factor is 25, and since it is INVERSELY 
proportional, you DIVIDE by 25.  If you make your distance 10 times as far 
away, the force is 1/100 of what it was.

As for WHY so many things follow the inverse square law, well, gravity, 
luminosity, and other energetic 'things' that follow the inverse square law 
can be thought about as radiating outward in a sphere-like shape - so think 
about the surface area of that sphere - which is 4πr².  So as gravity gets 
farther from the source, it is spreading out over an area of that sphere 
that is increasing in proportion to the square of the radius of the sphere 
- - ergo, the intensity decreases in proportion to the square of the radius.

In other words, if you increase the radius of a sphere by 'x', the surface 
area increases by a factor of x².  If you assume that the surface area 
represents a magnitude of some force which remains constant no matter how 
big the sphere gets, then at any point locally on that sphere, the 
magnitude of that force is inversely proportional to the square of the 
radius.  Gravity works the same way.  The distance between you and some 
source of gravity can be considered the radius of a sphere which you are on 
the edge of, and the source of gravity is at its center.

Make sense?

comments.author: TytonicDaCarrot

comments.text:
It's a two-way "road". Both the more massive and the less massive object 
are attracted to each other with the same force, but to move the more 
massive one a stronger force is needed. Actually, if only two objects 
existed, the less massive would simply move faster, but both would 
accelerate and move. What happens in an actual scenario is that a great 
massive object like a planet attracts (and is attracted to) everything in 
his surrounding, and usually all those forces nullify each other, while the 
lighter objects don't have balancing forces to stop them and must move 
towards the planet.
